Twitter as Tribal

218 words written on Thu, May 15 2008

Michael Lopp on Twitter:

The act of one human being choosing to follow another is a big deal. As long as nefarious intent is not in play, the connection creates what the social science nerds like to call an affinity map; by drawing a line between you and me, we can infer that weâ€™re somehow connected. How are we connected? Who knows? Maybe you like nerd culture? How about gel pens? Weâ€™re not really going to know until we test that link by asking a question.

â€¦Iâ€™m eagerly watching Twitter evolve and organize itself. Iâ€™m dazzled as third parties are giving Twitter memory and context. But what I care about, and what has value to me, is the tribe of people in my ecosystem. Twitter is the best social network out there;, itâ€™s a great social search engine;, and itâ€™s a short strategic hop from being a terrific next generation address book.

My tribe is not your tribe because youâ€™re not using Twitter how I do. You wrote an Academy Award winning screenplay, only follow a few people, but have thousands following you. You sell shoes and follow each of the thousands of people who follow you. You are a major airline, but sound surprisingly human.

Twitterâ€™s value has nothing to do with the technology.
